title: Biden Emphasizes Foreign Policy Background Amid Iran Tensions

title: Will the U.S. and Iran Blunder Into War?
summary: There are grave risks of miscalculation on both sides. Here are some questions to ask.. Political decisions are almost always shrouded in uncertainty. Wise policy makers will try to anticipate a wide range of possible outcomes and do what is possible to prepare for each of them.

title: The Christian Case for Trump
summary: It's myopic to focus on his personal behavior when important moral issues like abortion are at stake.. But a recent editorial calling for President Trump's removal through impeachment confirmed the magazine's creep toward that Slough of Despond populated by liberal elites and Joe Biden.

title: I Support Trump's Tariffs but Need an Exemption

title: The Jury Is Still Out on Elvis
summary: He might have left the building, but he shows up often in the courts.. Elvis Aaron Presley would be 85 Wednesday. While he died in 1977, there's one building he hasn't left: the courthouse.

title: 'Trade Is Not a Four-Letter Word' Review: Bargain Shopping Across the Globe
summary: Foreign competition brings about lower costs and better quality. Even "American-made" goods feature components from all over the world.. Fred Hochberg may seem like an unlikely instructor in the beauties of free trade. During eight years of the Obama administration he ran the Export-Import Bank, which promotes and finances U.S. exports with taxpayer dollars and is seldom linked with the phrase laissez-faire. Even so, the onetime direct-marketing specialist and lately a university lecturer presents a sprightly and clear-eyed testimonial to the value of globalization in "Trade Is Not a Four-Letter Word." President Trump and his in-house trade maven, Peter Navarro, could profit from his observation that, contrary to presidential tweets, "trade wars typically don't have winners." Of course, Mr. Hochberg is savvy enough to know that trade is never free of goals fashioned by politicians, and he acknowledges that trade wars, while often costly, "are nowhere near as devastating as actual wars."

title: Iraq Oil Industry's Progress Is Threatened by Tensions
summary: Security risks, talk of U.S. sanctions jeopardize Iraq's efforts to boost investment from U.S., European oil majors.. Iraq's hopes of rivaling Saudi Arabia for regional oil dominance, already hurt by a pullback in foreign investment, are facing new challenges from escalating conflict and threats of sanctions from President Trump, say oil executives and Iraqi officials.

title: New York Restaurant Owner Agrees to $240,000 Settlement
summary: State attorney general investigated Ken Friedman's alleged sexual misconduct. Veteran New York City restaurateur Ken Friedman and his Spotted Pig establishment will have to pay $240,000 to 11 former employees, as a result of a settlement reached with the New York state attorney general's office that followed an investigation into Mr. Friedman's alleged sexual misconduct.

title: Readers Debate Bobby Jindal's Ideas on Health Care
summary: President Trump can unilaterally peg Medicare prices to what Europe pays for pharmaceuticals. At that point, Europe could no longer free ride and would have to ask itself just how much it was willing to pay to keep new drug discoveries flowing.. Gov. Bobby Jindal argues that Republicans should fight for "equity" in drug development costs "through trade agreements, international rules and direct negotiations" ("How the GOP Can Win on Health Care", op-ed, Jan. 3). Actually, it's simpler than that. President Trump can unilaterally peg Medicare prices to what Europe pays for pharmaceuticals. At that point, Europe could no longer free ride and would have to ask itself just how much it was willing to pay to keep new drug discoveries flowing.

title: IKEA to Pay $46 Million to Parents of Child Killed by Falling Dresser
summary: The family of the two year old said it would donate $1 million to organizations advocating for more rigorous stability testing for dressers. STOCKHOLM-IKEA has agreed to pay $46 million to the parents of a California toddler who was killed when one of the Swedish furniture company's dressers fell on him.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Point, Click, Own: Firms Transform How to Buy Investment Homes
summary: Resume Subscription. This article is part of a Property Report package looking at small investors and real estate, from new ways for individuals to buy slices of office towers to how real estate crowdfunding is changing to survive.

title: Ford Vehicle Sales Declined 3.2% in 2019
summary: No. 2 U.S. auto maker sold about 2.41 million vehicles last year. Ford Motor Co. 's U.S. sales were off 3.2% in 2019, reflecting a broader cooling of demand in the U.S. auto market after a record period of elevated results.

title: 'It Was a Horror': Students Attacked by Masked Marauders at an Indian University
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW DELHI-An attack by a mob of hooded people on students at a prominent Indian university sparked widespread condemnation and student demonstrations, with university and government officials promising an investigation and politicians blaming each other for the spasm of violence.

title: Japan Vows to Tighten Airport Security Following Ghosn Escape
summary: One option being considered is using GPS tracking, as new details emerge about former Nissan chairman's movements. Japan's justice minister said the country would tighten security to make it harder for defendants like Carlos Ghosn to escape, and she said one option was using global-positioning system tracking.

title: U.S. Adds Troops to Mideast, Iranians Vow Revenge at General's Funeral
summary: Powerful commander's successor calls for removal of U.S. from the region; Pentagon says no plans to pull out of Iraq. The Pentagon said it plans to send B-52 bombers and more troops to the Mideast as anger simmered Monday in Baghdad and Tehran over the U.S.'s targeted killing of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani in Iraq.

title: Plant-Based Meat Makers Want Fake Pork on Your Fork
summary: Impossible Foods to introduce imitation ground pork and sausage, including patty for Burger King. After biting into the U.S. burger business, plant-based food makers are targeting pork.

title: Asbestos Costs Drive Owens-Illinois Affiliate to Bankruptcy
summary: An affiliate of one of the world's largest glassmakers said it would establish a bankruptcy trust to handle claims from people who say they were harmed by products containing asbestos. An affiliate of Owens-Illinois Group Inc., one of the world's largest manufacturers of glass container products, filed for bankruptcy Monday under the weight of thousands of asbestos injury claims.

title: In Carlos Ghosn's Escape, Plotters Exploited an Airport Security Hole
summary: An operative helping with the plan found security flaw at an Osaka airport that proved crucial. About three months before former auto titan Carlos Ghosn's escape last week from Japan to Lebanon, an operative helping plan his extraction visited Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Japan, and realized there was a huge security hole, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Cuomo Says State Will Acquire Block in Manhattan to Expand Penn Station
summary: Governor doesn't say how much it would cost, says eight new tracks could be built. New York state will take the lead on expanding Pennsylvania Station by acquiring an entire block in Manhattan to add eight new tracks, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said.

title: Additional Iran-Related Sanctions by U.S. May Have Little Impact, Sanctions Experts Say
summary: Policy analysts say more sanctions might not pressure Iran to come to a negotiated solution. Sanctions observers expect the U.S. to impose more sanctions on Iranian officials or companies that trade with Iran as tensions escalate between Tehran and Washington following a U.S. airstrike that killed an Iranian military leader.

title: U.S. Could Begin Deporting Mexican Asylum Seekers to Guatemala
summary: Move expands Trump administration's controversial agreement with Central American nation. WASHINGTON-The U.S. could begin deporting Mexican asylum seekers to Guatemala, where they can file asylum claims in the Central American country instead, according to the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Murders Increased in New York City Last Year
summary: NYPD data show the number rose 8%, even as overall serious crime declined. New York City recorded a rise in murders, shootings, robberies and assaults in 2019, even as overall serious crime fell, New York Police Department officials said Monday.

title: Bolton Willing to Testify in Trump Impeachment Trial
summary: Former adviser's statement spurs partisan wrangling over how proceedings would be conducted. WASHINGTON-Former national security adviser John Bolton, described by witnesses who testified at President Trump's impeachment hearings as alarmed at the pressure put on Ukraine, said he would testify in a Senate trial if subpoenaed by lawmakers.

title: Husband of Chief of Staff to New York Assembly Speaker Arrested on Drug Charge
summary: Orlando Dennis is charged with conspiring to import cocaine worth $100,000. The husband of the chief of staff to New York state Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie was charged Monday with conspiring to import cocaine worth $100,000, according to the Brooklyn U.S. attorney's office.

title: Trump's Post-Soleimani World
summary: He now has to manage the consequences of his deterrent strike.. It may be true that no good deed goes unpunished, but only the ever-active Donald Trump could take it upon himself to punish his own good deed.

title: Venezuela's Latest Coup
summary: Maduro steals legislative power, the last peaceful opening for change.. Hope for restoring Venezuelan democracy took another hit Sunday when dictator Nicolás Maduro's security forces blocked opposition lawmakers from entering the National Assembly ahead of a vote for a new president of the chamber of deputies. The move was so brazen that even Mexico and Argentina, leftist allies of Caracas, objected.

title: Climate of Investment Fear
summary: Insurers and banks bow to progressives and divest from fossil fuels.. Climate crusaders are failing to persuade voters to limit fossil fuels, but they're turning to coercion by other means. They're having some success with U.S. banks and insurers that are caving to pressure to divest from carbon energy.

title: The Terrorist Horn of Africa
summary: How were Kenyan and U.S. troops surprised by al-Shabaab?. Militants from the al Qaeda-affiliated al-Shabaab terrorist group killed a U.S. service member and two Pentagon contractors Sunday during a raid on the Manda Bay Airfield in Kenya. The attack raises questions about America's alertness in the region and is a reminder of the importance of the African counterterrorism mission.

title: Aramark's New CFO to Help Shift Focus Toward Revenue Growth
summary: The Philadelphia-based food-services provider also recently gained a new CEO and activist part-owner. Aramark tapped a new finance chief on Monday as the food-services company looks to usher in a new era under a recently hired chief executive and the minority ownership of an activist fund that has sought executive changes.

title: Buttigieg's War and 'The Shortest Way Home'
summary: Arriving in Afghanistan, he thought of John Kerry. It's a telling comparison, and an unflattering one.. When Mayor Pete Buttigieg talks about his military service, his opponents fall silent, the media fall in love, and his political prospects soar. Veterans roll their eyes.

title: Will the Gentleman From the Underworld Yield?
summary: Trump's impeachment is the devil's work-an event in which everyone involved comes out looking bad.. 'The devil's work" suggests something awful and unbearably painful to endure-but a friend of mine, not a theologian but a psychiatrist, defined it in 1991 as an event in which everyone comes out looking bad. He had in mind the Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas controversy.
